title-group.article-title: A New Nanotechnology for Imaging the Juxta‐Articular Intraosseous Vasculature‐Canal Complex and Related Clinical Pilot Studies

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The objective of this study is to achieve distinct visualization of juxta‐articular intraosseous microvessels, a novel nanoimaging methodology in which superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles and meglumine diatrizoate (MD) are used cooperatively was implemented.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A newly created composite of MD and Fe3O4 nanoparticles (MD‐Fe3O4 NPs) was prepared as a contrast agent to achieve efficacious imaging of the juxta‐articular intraosseous vasculature‐canal complex (JIVCC). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) were employed to observe the structural characteristics and binding stability of the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. In 20 rabbits that received an injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, 1‐mm‐thick computed tomography (CT) scanning was performed for radiographic assessment. Hematoxylin–eosin‐ and potassium ferrocyanide‐stained sections from 10 sacrificed rabbits were used to observe the histological characteristics of JIVCC with MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, and the remaining 10 rabbits were utilized for a systemic safety evaluation. After a healthy volunteer received an MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection, we also performed CT scanning and related safety evaluations.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: When the MD nanoparticles and amino‐Fe3O4 nanoparticles were mixed together, they aggregated into a stable compound structure according to microscopic observations and SEM–EDS verification. In 20 rabbits receiving MD‐Fe3O4 injections, 1‐mm slice CT imaging demonstrated significantly enhanced visualization of the JIVCCs in magnet‐placed knees compared to contralateral limbs (tibial JIVCC: p < 0.001; femoral JIVCC: p < 0.001), confirming MD‐Fe3O4 NPs as the efficacious magnetic contrast enhancer. The histological characteristics of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in JIVCC were revealed. The levels of serum iron before and 4 and 72 h after MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection were 23.9 ± 2.13 μmol/L, 26.2 ± 2.30 μmol/L, and 24.9 ± 2.33 μmol/L, respectively, indicating that there was no significant difference in safety (p = 0.092). After a volunteer received MD‐Fe3O4 NPs via intravenous administration, the JIVCC was clearly visualized, laboratory tests of serum iron levels were normal, and no injection‐related complications occurred.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A novel compound nanoparticle, which achieved satisfactory overall outcomes, was implemented as an appropriate alternative for the discernible visualization of juxta‐articular intraosseous microvessels. The nanotechnology utilized in this study may augment the clinical imaging methodology for the osseous vascular system.

abstract.p: The schematic diagram of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs application. MD‐Fe3O4 nanoparticle is efficacious to realize the visualization of juxta‐articular intraosseous microvessels. The application of MD‐Fe3O4 nanoparticle can serve as a warranted clinical imaging method.

institution-wrap.institution: the Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province

p.mixed-citation: M.Dou, J.Yang, J.Li, et al., “A New Nanotechnology for Imaging the Juxta‐Articular Intraosseous Vasculature‐Canal Complex and Related Clinical Pilot Studies,” Orthopaedic Surgery17, no. 9 (2025): 2744–2755, 10.1111/os.70149.PMC1240487040787768

Kun Cheng, Guanghui Wang, Jing Li, Xia Su, and Xianhao Shao contributed equally to this work and are joint corresponding authors.

def.p: scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectrum

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The long bones perform considerable physiological functions in the musculoskeletal system, such as weight bearing, motion, and inorganic salt metabolism, in which the intraosseous vasculatures play a vital role [1, 2]. In 2019, Grüneboom et al. explored a network of trans‐cortical vessels (TCVs), which significantly advanced the understanding of the cortical vasculature, and their data indicated that TCVs are a central component of the cortical circulatory system in long bones with important physiological functions and clinical value [3, 4]. However, new anatomical discoveries of the juxta‐articular intraosseous vasculature system have been rare in recent decades [5, 6], and the paucity of efficient specific imaging technology for such structures is an important constraint.

Currently, several challenges exist in in vivo imaging technology for microvessels in human bones, taking into account both exact visualization and potential large‐scale clinical application. Currently, bone scintigraphy and laser scanning are preliminarily applied for tracking intraosseous vessels. However, volunteers have to suffer several hours for continuous tracking and postprocessing when undertaking such methodologies, which are uncertainly regarded as facile clinical routines in the future [4, 7]. Fluorescence microscopy, which is an imaging method that can be used to observe osseous capillaries and examine their hemodynamic features, is also not an appropriate choice for routine clinical work because of its high cost [3, 8]. Magnetic resonance imaging with high field and spatial resolution may currently contribute to the recognition of trans‐cortical and intraosseous vasculatures, but this radiographic technique often results in inevitable discontinuities in tiny blood vessels [9, 10]. Moreover, these methods are utilized to scan diaphyseal vessels rather than juxta‐articular intraosseous microvessels. In recent years, some scholars have attempted to use submillimeter‐resolution steady‐state magnetic resonance angiography to detect small arteries in the femoral head in vivo. Intraosseous vascular fragments can be observed, but sagittal and coronal reconstruction images of these vessels often lose their continuity, and such angiography is performed only for the small arteries in the proximal femoral region [11]. MicroCT, the preeminent imaging technology for bony microarchitecture, also seems impractical for visualizing juxta‐articular intraosseous soft tissues [12].

Intraosseous and transosseous vessels in the epiphyseal and metaphyseal regions play important roles in diverse orthopedic diseases (e.g., ischemic osteonecrosis, articular cartilage degeneration, bone neoplasm, osseous tuberculosis) [13, 14, 15, 16]. The theoretical basis of this clinical phenomenon is that these vasculatures present potential “breakpoints” on the bone cortex, cartilage, or subchondral bone plate to facilitate the dissemination of tumor cells or pathogens between the intraosseous and extraosseous compartments. Specifically, the existence of these tiny vessels and their bony canals provides anatomic spaces that can conceal pathogenic factors from operative curettage or resection and facilitate lesion invasion. In our previous studies, we conducted a retrospective study to investigate the general oncological implications of juxta‐articular intraosseous vessels. On this basis, we found that juxta‐articular vasculature‐canal complexes increase and accelerate the local recurrence and tumor dissemination of bone neoplasms in the subchondral area around the knee. In patients with lesion invasion of the subchondral vasculature‐canal complex, we observed a higher recurrence rate and shorter relapse period than in those with lesions in other femoral or tibial intraosseous regions after the same surgical treatments. The occurrence of these clinical phenomena may be related to difficulty in conducting thorough tumor curettage or resection in the subchondral vasculature‐canal complex via a high‐speed burr and electrocautery, which are usually selected to achieve an extensively safe margin of the lesion in cancellous and cortical bone, since such an anatomic structure is easy to ignore because of its small size. Therefore, a safe and practical imaging method could benefit a wide range of patients because the distinct imaging of juxta‐articular intraosseous vessels can be established for extensive clinical application. Superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIONs) are magnetic responsive nanoparticles that have been widely investigated in the mechanical, electronic, optical, chemical, and biomedical fields [17, 18, 19, 20, 21]. In previous studies, the utilization of SPIONs combined with charged drug micelles as carriers not only achieved better therapeutic effects but also guaranteed safety for clinical perfusion therapy [22]. Therefore, in theory, orchestrated magnetic compound microparticles can enable SPIONs to carry contrast medium to implement effective and reliable imaging of epiphyseal and metaphyseal intraosseous microvessels.

This study is based on our previous discovery of the juxta‐articular intraosseous vasculature‐canal complex (JIVCC) (also called the LC complex in the knee joint), which has been described in the anatomic, radiographic, histologic, and surgical fields (Figure 1) [5, 6], hoping to explore an efficient imaging method for JIVCC that is suitable for clinical promotion. We plan to use amino‐Fe3O4 nanoparticles to adsorb meglumine diatrizoate (MD) as a contrast medium and create a novel composite of MD and Fe3O4 nanoparticles (MD‐Fe3O4 NPs) to achieve the imaging of JIVCC in vivo. This investigation aims to (I) explore the characteristics of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs that are suitable for JIVCC nanoimaging; (II) investigate the chemical, radiographical, and histological features of this nanoimaging technology and verify its rationality and safety; (III) elucidate the clinical feasibility and potential clinical significance of this new imaging method.

caption.p: Schematic figure for the anatomic and microarchitectural features of juxta‐articular intraosseous vasculature‐canal complex (JIVCC). (A) The gross anatomical dissection showing a femoral JIVCC arteriole (empty arrowhead) originated from the branches of middle genicular artery (empty arrow), and a femoral and a tibial JIVCC venules (arrowheads) originated from the tributaries of the middle genicular vein (arrow). (B) Bony canal of a femoral JIVCC (dashed line) shown on reconstructed sagittal microCT images. (C) Bony canal of a tibial JIVCC (dashed line) shown on reconstructed coronal microCT images. Source: Adapted from Reference [5]. Copyright © 2021 Shao, Li, Zhang, Yao, Sun, Li, Liu, Hou, Li, Li, Gao, Yang, Li, Li and Cheng under CC BY.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: This study was reviewed and approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of Shandong University (No. LL‐2016‐1‐040). Twenty SPF New Zealand rabbits (purchased from Qingdao Kangda Biotechnology Co. Ltd., China) were used in this investigation, and a volunteer (one of the researchers of this study) received an injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs.

sec.title: MD‐Fe3O4 NP Preparation and Electron Microscope Analysis
sec.p: We purchased 20°C compound MD injection (GYZZ H37023984, Lunanbeite Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd., China) and amino‐Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticle dispersion agent (100 nm, 10 mL: 50 mg [Tianjin Beisile Chromatographic Technology Development Center, China]) for this research. Half of the dose of the MD and one dose of SPION solution were mixed for the injection of each experimental rabbit. When the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were prepared, an oscillator was used to oscillate at a frequency of 200 times/min for 5 min. The morphology, size, and elemental composition of the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JEM‐1200EXII, JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) and evaluated by SEM and energy dispersive spectrum (SEM–EDS) analytic system (JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan), as were the stability of the compound particles. For SEM–EDS analysis, the well‐prepared MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were mounted appropriately and subjected to microanalysis via a Bruker Nano Berlin instrument. The ultrastructures of the examined MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were analyzed at a primary energy of 10 keV. For the tested samples, maps of the distribution of elements, including O, Fe, C, N, and I, were generated.

sec.title: CT Scanning of MD‐Fe3O4 NP‐Injected Rabbits In Vivo
sec.p: After general anesthesia and fixation, the unilateral lower limb of each experimental rabbit was abducted, a 50 × 30 × 10 mm3 neodymium magnet was placed parallel to the targeted femoral or tibial JIVCC around the knee joint, and the contralateral lower extremity was also abducted for a control experiment. One‐millimeter‐thick computed tomography (CT) (Definition Flash, Siemens, Germany) scanning was performed, and the images were coronal, sagittal, and three‐dimensional reconstructed to detect the radiographic characteristics of the JIVCC. All the imaging data were reviewed by two experienced radiologists.

sec.title: Histological Section of MD‐Fe3O4 NP‐Injected JIVCC
sec.p: Ten experimental rabbits were sacrificed to harvest MD‐Fe3O4 NP‐injected JIVCC. The obtained knee joints were frozen in a deep freezer (−86°C) (DW‐86L338, Qingdao Haier Company, China) and then cut in the frozen state. After being immersed in formaldehyde solution for 7 days, the samples were soaked in EDTA decalcifying solution for another 14 days for decalcification. The proximal tibia and distal femur were sectioned and stained with hematoxylin–eosin (HE) (Nanchang Yulu Experimental Equipment Co. Ltd., China) and potassium ferrocyanide (Shanghai Yuanye Bio‐Technology Co. Ltd., China), and the histological characteristics of JIVCC with MD‐Fe3O4 nanocomposite particles were observed via an Olympus IX‐70 microscope (IX‐70, Tokyo, Japan).

sec.title: Safety Testing for MD‐Fe3O4 NP Application
sec.p: The remaining 10 rabbits were fed as usual after regaining consciousness from anesthesia, and urine volume, color, and precipitation were observed for 48 h after anesthesia. To verify whether the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were excreted, we collected urinary and enteric excreta to search for potential discharged magnetic nanoparticles under the action of a magnetic field. For a quantitative safety evaluation, the blood samples from all 10 rabbits were digested for 5 min, filtered, and diluted with deionized water. The digests were subjected to an air/acetylene fast sequential flame atomic absorption spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) to determine the serum Fe concentration. Serum ferric levels were determined three times before the injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, 4 h after the injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, and 3 days after the injection.

sec.title: Radiographic Analysis and Safety Testing for an MD‐Fe3O4 NP‐Injected Volunteer
sec.p: On the basis of the safety assessment for MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in experimental rabbits and the sterility of the reagent, a volunteer received MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection and CT scanning. The MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were injected via the dorsal hand vein, and a larger N35 neodymium magnet (Shanghai Genchang Electromechanical Company, China) with a meter magnet of 850 G was closely attached to the knee joint and placed parallel to the targeted femoral or tibial JIVCC to provide a magnetic field. The 1‐mm‐thick CT scan of the knee joint was performed at 1 min after the injection. The JIVCCs were also observed on the coronal and sagittal reconstructed CT images. The serum ferric levels of the volunteer were determined three times: before the injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, 4 h after the injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, and 2 weeks after the injection [23]. Whether related complications occurred was also recorded.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: SPSS 21.0 (IBM Corp., USA) was used for all the statistical calculations in this investigation. Fisher's precision probability test was performed to statistically compare the number of discernible contrasted JIVCCs before and after MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection. The chi‐square test was applied for the statistical comparison of the histological detection rate of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in JIVCCs between the experimental side with a magnetic field and the contralateral lower extremity. A paired t‐test was performed to analyze significant differences in the 48‐h urine volume of the experimental rabbits before and after MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection. The serum ferric level was analyzed via one‐way ANOVA, followed by Fisher's least significant difference post hoc test for comparisons between two groups. p < 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Characteristics of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs
sec.p: Under transmission electron microscopy, we observed that single diatrizoated meglumine particles with a diameter of 20 ± 2 nm presented as regular spheres and were uniformly dispersed in the solution (Figure 2A). The amino‐Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles with a diameter of 100 ± 10 nm presented as microspherical clusters and were also dispersed in solution (Figure 2B). When the two types of nanoparticles are mixed together, they automatically aggregate into a stable compound structure under neutralization adsorption (Figure 2C). The stable combination of MD and amino‐Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles was also verified by SEM (Figure 2D–F).

caption.p: Characteristics of meglumine diatrizoate nanoparticles, amino‐Fe3O4 nanoparticles, and MD‐Fe3O4 NPs under electron microscopy. (A) Regular spherical meglumine diatrizoate nanoparticles (20 ± 2 nm) under TEM. Scale bar, 100 nm. (B) Regular spherical amino‐Fe3O4 nanoparticles (100 ± 10 nm) under TEM. Scale bar, 200 nm. (C) MD‐Fe3O4 NPs showing a stable combination under TEM, with no free Fe3O4 or MD nanoparticles. Scale bar, 200 nm. (D) SEM image of regular spherical meglumine diatrizoate nanoparticles (20 ± 2 nm). Scale bar, 100 nm. (E) SEM image of regular spherical amino‐Fe3O4 nanoparticles (100 ± 10 nm). Scale bar, 100 nm. (F) SEM image of the stable combination of well‐prepared MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, which showed no free Fe3O4 or MD nanoparticles. Scale bar, 100 nm.

sec.p: After the well‐prepared MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were established and scanned (Figure 3A), the contained elements were examined via SEM–EDS analysis (Figure 3B–H). The Fe that only existed in amino‐Fe3O4 and I that only existed in MD were distributed in equilibrium, indicating that the MD and Fe3O4 nanoparticles were uniformly combined (Figure 3D,G). There was no part presenting a lopsided concentration of either only Fe3O4 or only MD (Figure 3H). Overall, the MD with a diameter of 20 ± 2 nm and the amino‐Fe3O4 with a diameter of 100 ± 10 nm are two suitable nanoparticles with satisfactory particular sizes, superparamagnetic characteristics, and aggregation forces to form the compound MD‐Fe3O4 NPs.

caption.p: SEM–EDS analysis and mapping of the element distribution in the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. (A) SEM image of well‐prepared MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. (B) Energy dispersive spectrum analysis of each element in the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. (C–H) Maps of the distribution of each element, including O (C), Fe (D), C (E), N (F), and I (G), in the well‐prepared MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. (H) Total distribution of all the elements.

sec.title: Radiographic Characteristics of MD‐Fe3O4 NP‐Injected JIVCC
sec.p: After the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were injected into the ear vein of 20 eligible rabbits, the contrast agents were immediately concentrated in the liver and urinary system, including the kidney, ureter, and bladder. In the knee joint set with the neodymium magnet (Figure 4A), clear images of JIVCCs in both the proximal tibia and distal femur were displayed under 1‐mm‐thick CT scanning and corresponding reconstructed images in all 20 experimental rabbits (Figure 4B,C). The JIVCC development rate after MD‐Fe3O4 NP infusion was significantly greater than that before injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs (tibial JIVCC: χ 2 = 40, p < 0.001; femoral JIVCC: χ 2 = 40, p < 0.001). Moreover, no enhanced JIVCC imaging of the contralateral extremity was presented, which was significantly different from that of the knee joint placed with the neodymium magnet (tibial JIVCC: χ 2 = 40, p < 0.001; femoral JIVCC: χ 2 = 40, p < 0.001).

caption.p: Radiographic and histological findings of MD‐Fe3O4 NP‐injected rabbits. (A) Experimental rabbits underwent CT scanning, and the neodymium magnet is shown as a high‐density rectangle. (B) Discernible imaging of intraosseous microvessels in the proximal tibial JIVCC (arrowhead) shown on a 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed CT image after intravenous injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. (C) Discernible imaging of intraosseous microvessels in the distal femoral JIVCC (arrowhead) shown on a 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed CT image after intravenous injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. (D) MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were found as irregular brown substances (arrowhead) via HE staining in the rabbit JIVCC. (E) MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were found as irregular blue substances (arrowhead) via potassium ferrocyanide staining in the rabbit JIVCC.

sec.title: Histological Characteristics of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in JIVCC
sec.p: The histological characteristics of the 10 rabbits that were sacrificed were revealed. Under HE staining, irregular brown particles were found in the intraosseous blood vessels, which were aggregated with MD‐Fe3O4 NPs (Figure 4D). These magnetic composite particles were also identified as irregular blue substances via potassium ferrocyanide staining (Figure 4E). The histological characteristics of the cells adjacent to the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were normal, and no cellular injury or necrosis was detected (Figure 4D,E). The detection rate of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in the JIVCC of the knee joint on the side with a magnet was significantly greater than that on the side without a magnet (χ 2 = 7.5, p = 0.020).

sec.title: Safety Verification of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs In Vivo
sec.p: The urine volume of the 10 surviving rabbits was 519.5 ± 61.3 mL 48 h after anesthesia and recovery, and there was no statistically significant difference from the urine volume of 503.5 ± 57.8 mL 48 h before the MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection experiment (t = −1.329, p = 0.216) (Table 1). The urine presented a light yellow color, in which the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were excreted as dark brown flocculent precipitates.

caption.p: Urine volume and serum iron level in rabbits before and after MD‐Fe3O4 NPs injection.

fn.p: Abbreviation: MD‐Fe3O4 NPs: meglumine diatrizoate and Fe3O4 nanoparticles.

sec.p: We collected urine and feces from 10 rabbits after MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection, extracted, purified, and dissolved them, prepared 100 mL of phosphate‐buffered saline solution, and converted 3 mL of the iron content into 0.28 ± 0.04 mg of Fe3O4 through biochemical analyzer measurements. The iron levels in the blood before the experiment, 4 h after the experiment, and 72 h after the experiment were 23.9 ± 2.13 μmol/L, 26.2 ± 2.30 μmol/L, and 24.9 ± 2.33 μmol/L, respectively, with no statistical difference (F = 2.614, p = 0.092) (Table 1). Based on the above findings, MD‐Fe3O4 NPs can be excreted from urine and feces to guarantee physiological safety in vivo. In addition, no siderosis was observed in the livers or spleens of any of the experimental animals.

sec.title: Clinical Perfusion of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs
sec.p: Following placement of the neodymium magnet (Figure 5A), a volunteer received MD‐Fe3O4 NP intravenous administration as a contrast agent, and 1‐mm‐thick CT scanning of the knee joint was performed. The intraosseous vasculatures in the JIVCC were clearly visualized in both the coronal and sagittal reconstructed images, indicating that this method can reliably develop for the JIVCC (Figure 5B–E). We observed radiographic materials from other male adults as a control. As a result, imaging of both proximal tibial and distal femoral JIVCCs can demonstrate only their vascular foramen on the articular facet and partial osseous canal but no distinct intraosseous microvessels on routine 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed coronal and sagittal CT images without the utilization of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs (Figure 5F–I). There was also no enhanced JIVCC imaging in the contralateral lower extremity without magnets in the volunteer, and the results were in accordance with those of the animal experiments.

caption.p: Characteristics of meglumine diatrizoate nanoparticles, amino‐Fe3O4 nanoparticles, and MD‐Fe3O4 NPs under electron microscopy. (A) Preimaging immediate anteroposterior radiograph of the volunteer; the neodymium magnet is shown as a high‐density rectangle. (B) Discernible imaging of intraosseous microvessels in the distal femoral JIVCC (arrowhead) shown on a 1 mm‐thick reconstructed sagittal CT image after intravenous injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in a volunteer. (C) Discernible imaging of intraosseous microvessels in the distal femoral JIVCC (arrowhead) shown on a 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed coronal CT image after intravenous injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in a volunteer. (D) Discernible imaging of intraosseous microvessels in the proximal tibial JIVCC (arrowhead) shown on a 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed sagittal CT image after intravenous injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in a volunteer. (E) Discernible imaging of intraosseous microvessels in the proximal tibial JIVCC (arrowhead) shown on a 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed coronal CT image after intravenous injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in a volunteer. (F) Imaging of distal femoral JIVCC showing its vascular foremen on the articular facet (arrowhead) and osseous canal (arrow) but no distinct intraosseous microvessels on a routine 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed sagittal CT image of a healthy femur from an adult male. (G) Imaging of distal femoral JIVCC showing its vascular foremen on the articular facet (arrowhead) and osseous canal (arrow) but no distinct intraosseous microvessels on a routine 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed coronal CT image of a healthy femur from an adult male. (H) Imaging of proximal tibial JIVCC showing its vascular foremen on the articular facet (arrowhead) and osseous canal (arrow) but no distinct intraosseous microvessels on a routine 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed sagittal CT image of a healthy tibia from an adult male. (I) Imaging of proximal tibial JIVCC showing its vascular foremen on the articular facet (arrowhead) and osseous canal (arrow) but no distinct intraosseous microvessels on a routine 1‐mm‐thick reconstructed coronal CT image of a healthy tibia from an adult male.

sec.p: The iron levels in the blood before the experiment, 4 h after the experiment, and 2 weeks after the experiment were 17.7 μmol/L, 19.8 μmol/L, and 18.2 μmol/L, respectively, all within the normal safe range, and no adverse events were observed following injection, which demonstrated the safe application of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs in humans (Figure 6).

caption.p: Serum iron levels in the volunteer before MD‐Fe3O4 NP injection, 4 h after injection, and 2 weeks after injection, showing the safe range. The red lines above and below represent the maximum and minimum limits of the safe concentration of serum iron, respectively.

sec.title: The Main Findings of This Study
sec.p: In this investigation, we created a compound nanoparticle composed of MD and SPIONs to facilitate the entrance of contrast agents to intraosseous microvessels, such as JIVCCs, which are arduous steps in previous radiographic studies. We found that these newly synthesized MD‐Fe3O4 NPs possess adaptable chemical, radiographical, and histological features to achieve the nanoimaging of JIVCC, and their rationality and reliability were validated in vivo. Moreover, studies of not only animal models but also human blood vessels were carried out to verify that this novel imaging methodology can guarantee both feasibility and safety for further clinical application. To the best of our knowledge, a systematic investigation describing nanoimaging technologies for the juxta‐articular intraosseous vascular system has not been reported in the previous English literature, and MD‐Fe3O4 NPs were proven to be efficacious, acceptable, and safe for entering such a vascular system through intravenous administration in this investigation.

sec.title: Key Points for Successful Implementation of MD‐Fe3O4 NP Imaging of the JIVCC
sec.p: In this study, we summarize some experiences with the optimized implementation of MD‐Fe3O4 NP imaging of JIVCC to facilitate its wider application. First, it is important to be familiar with the origin of JIVCCs and the location where they enter the epiphysis and metaphysis to ensure the uneventful completion of such nanoimaging technology [5, 6]. The contrast agent‐enhanced locations of JIVCC on the articular facet of the distal femur and proximal tibia are in accordance with the previously described areas, thus guaranteeing the rationality and dependability of applying MD‐Fe3O4 NPs for the visualization of JIVCC on the basis of anatomical evidence [5]. Second, we found that the 100 ± 10 nm SPION consisted of Fe3O4 core particles and amino shells combined with 20 ± 2 nm diatrizoated meglumine particles to form composite nanoparticles for JIVCC imaging, resulting in a stable interparticle combination with maps of the equalized distribution of each element [24, 25, 26]. Finally, when performing JIVCC imaging, we recommend that the magnet should be placed parallel to the targeted JIVCC to ensure the stability and continuity of vascular imaging to the greatest extent. If the magnet is placed vertically, the imaging will be unstable, and the images will be disturbed due to the accelerated flow of magnetic microspheres, dot aggregation, and other potential reasons [27, 28].

sec.title: Rationality and Safety of MD‐Fe3O4 NP Imaging for JIVCC
sec.p: Currently, ferumoxytol is the only SPION approved as a clinical contrast agent carrier and is utilized for contrast enhancement in radiographic detection and imaging [29, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34]. The rationality of this investigation is also supported by the anatomic characteristics of the JIVCC. On the basis of our previous findings, JIVCCs are firmly confined to the osseous canal with constant internal and external diameters regardless of whether these microvessels are filled, and there is basically no change in the phase of diastole or systole [5]. Therefore, the MD‐Fe3O4 NP contrast agent injected into the circulatory system can enter the JIVCC under natural pressure, providing a dynamic theoretical basis for the reasonable application of such nanoparticles [5, 35]. In recent studies in which Fe3O4‐based composite NPs were applied for biomedical imaging, histological observations were usually conducted between 1 and 48 h after injection in animal models to determine the adequate biodistribution of the composite nanoparticles [19, 36]. On the basis of these previous reliable experiences, we recorded the histological and cellular features of the sacrificed experimental animals 48 h after the injection to ensure a sufficient period of time for scientific evaluation. This study also demonstrated the safety of JIVCC imaging via MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, as described below. First, we focused on the histological characteristics of HE‐stained JIVCC cells adjacent to the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs and found no cytopathological changes or cell death. Second, previous studies have shown that ferumoxytol nanoparticles are distributed in various tissues and are mainly deposited in the liver and spleen, followed by the brain, heart, and lung, and that the bone is not the organ where SPION accumulates [37, 38]. Finally, the concentration of free iron both 4 h and 2 weeks after injection was within the safe range, and no related adverse reactions to injection occurred in this study [39]. Compared with previous Fe3O4 NP studies, we also found that the dynamic change trend of the ion concentration in our experimental animals was very similar to that of safe in vivo biodistribution behaviors and barely hepatic/splenic metallic accumulation [36]. Notably, ferumoxytol is regarded as the only clinical SPION‐derived product currently approved by the Food and Drug Administration [31]. Moreover, similar drug‐coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles have also been verified to have no immunogenicity that leads to unexpected immune responses or autoimmune diseases [40].

sec.title: Clinical Significance and Application Prospects of MD‐Fe3O4 NP Imaging of JIVCC
sec.p: This study provides a sufficient preliminary basis for extensive clinical radiographic applications of MD‐Fe3O4 NP imaging of JIVCC via CT and MRI under the induction of an appropriate magnetic field [36, 41]. The JIVCC imaging methodology for MD‐Fe3O4 NPs involves intravenous infusion, which is the most common clinical injection modality [31]. Moreover, the intra‐articular injection of MD‐Fe3O4 NPs can facilitate the intraoperative localization of JIVCC in minimally invasive treatment, arthroscopic surgery, and open surgery [42, 43]. SPIONs can also carry chemotherapy drugs such as doxorubicin to achieve precise antitumor treatment, which has been implemented in the treatment of malignant neoplasms, including breast, ovarian, and cervical cancers [31, 44]. The successful applications of SPIONs in previous oncologic studies indicate that the novel nanoimaging technology described in this study also possesses potential extensive prospects for clinical application in corresponding scopes, such as intraosseous precise chemotherapy of osseous malignant neoplasms such as osteosarcoma. In this study, the appropriate implementation of a magnetic field also played a vital role in the successful application of this new methodology. We plan to gradually establish the magnetic field as a standardized clinical workflow following the three stages described below. In the first stage, the external neodymium magnet may have to be physically placed around the joint with a parallel orientation to the targeted JIVCC, and this neodymium magnet is preferentially recommended to be placed in the lateral position in the anteroposterior direction. The external neodymium magnets can be fixed with the help of an assembled or 3D‐printed immobilization brace. In the second stage, we can simplify the setup of the magnetic field in the related surgeries by utilizing an internal neodymium magnet that can be attached to a hemoclip. The magnetic anchored setup can be placed into the intra‐articular‐oriented vessels for the targeted JIVCC (e.g., middle genicular veins for femoral and tibial JIVCCs), and the detailed procedures are similar to those of magnetic anchor‐guided endoscopic submucosal dissection [45]. In the last stage, we expect to implement a mature and stable electromagnetic field such as transcranial magnetic stimulation to finally realize a convenient routine clinical application of MD‐Fe3O4 NP nanoimaging methodology to visualize the intraosseous microvessels.

Currently, it is still arduous to implement large‐scale clinical investigations involving multiple patients for the studies focused on the intraosseous and transosseous microvessels and canals; therefore, initial observations of femoral, tibial, and fibular TCVs were first conducted on each single participant [3]. Moreover, many medical nanoimaging studies are currently only able to be conducted on experimental animals or cell lines, but without the verification of clinical participants due to diverse technological or security considerations [19, 25, 46]. Because of these inevitable limits, only one human volunteer was included in this clinical pilot study, and we plan to enroll more clinical cases in our future series studies to increase the broader applicability of this nanoimaging methodology. Furthermore, retrospective CT images that use MD as a contrast agent will also be included in follow‐up investigations to conduct a gradient comparison between MD‐Fe3O4 NPs, single MD injections, and other routine contrast agents for the clinical imaging effect of JIVCC.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: An important strength of our study design is the cooperative application of SPIONs and MD, which are both regarded as clinically reliable materials. They guarantee the safety and feasibility to realize the effective visualization of intraosseous microvessels. Besides, this nanoimaging technology was successfully implemented in the enrolled volunteer, indicating that this investigation design is very suitable for real clinical radiographic practices. The main limitations of our study are as follows. First, to ensure safety, the different temperatures and pH values were not adjusted in vivo to test the potentially variable properties of the MD‐Fe3O4 NPs. Moreover, it must be acknowledged that the number of volunteers enrolled in this study was limited, and the universality of our results should be further validated if large‐scale investigations are conducted in the future.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this investigation, we created a compound nanoparticle composed of MD and amino‐Fe3O4 to achieve contrast imaging of juxta‐articular intraosseous microvessels, which has been challenging in previous radiographic and orthopedic investigations. On the basis of not only animal models but also human blood vessels, this novel nanoimaging methodology is verified to guarantee both feasibility and safety and therefore can be further implemented for related clinical applications.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Kun Cheng, Guanghui Wang, Jing Li, Xia Su, and Xianhao Shao designed the study. Jianmin Li and Zhenzhong Li supervised the investigation. Mengmeng Dou and Jinfeng Yang conducted the majority of this study and analyzed data. Jiaoran Li and Xianhao Shao prepared the manuscript. Mengmeng Dou, Jinfeng Yang, Jiaoran Li, Kun Cheng, and Xianhao Shao helped with correlative imaging steps. Mengmeng Dou, Jinfeng Yang, and Xianhao Shao helped with radiographic observations and measurements. Kun Cheng and Jiaoran Li helped with histological examinations. Jianmin Li, Zhenzhong Li, Guanghui Wang, Jing Li, and Kun Cheng revised the manuscript. All authors contributed to the article and approved the submitted version.

sec.title: Ethics Statement
sec.p: The study was conducted according to the guidelines of the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of Medical School, Shandong University (No. LL‐2020‐1‐052).

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: The authors have nothing to report.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: The authors thank the Department of Pathology, Qilu Hospital (Qingdao) for histological determination. The authors thank the Department of Radiography, Qilu Hospital (Qingdao) and the Department of Radiography, Tianjin First Central Hospital, for radiographic verification. They extend their gratitude to the experimental support from Shandong Provincial Hospital. They also thank Dr. Shimo Yu for his professional guidance in the field of chemical analysis.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
